questions.text: The WHO has formulated a Global Action Plan for the prevention and control of non-communicable diseases. Which of the following is not a voluntary global target under this initiative?

choices.text: 10% relative reduction in harmful use of alcohol
30% relative reduction in mean population intake of sodium
10% relative reduction in prevalence of insufficient physical activity
10% relative  reduction in use of trans-fat for cooking

questions.solution:
A 10 percent relative reduction in the use of trans-fat for cooking is not a voluntary global target under the WHO Global Action Plan for prevention and control of non-communicable diseases.

There are 9 targets under this plan which are to be achieved by 2025. These are shown in the image below.

questions.text: Project MONICA is related to:
questions.solution:
Project MONICA is related to cardiovascular diseases.

It stands for multinational monitoring of trends and determinants in cardiovascular diseases. It was done to study the reasons for the changes in the trends of cardiovascular diseases in different countries.

World Heart Day is celebrated every year on the 29th of September. The theme for World Heart Day 2021 is "Use Heart to Connect".

World Heart Day 2023 theme was 'Use Heart, Know Heart'.

World Heart Day 2024 theme is 'ABCD- AnyBody Can Die'.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the relationship between smoking and coronary heart disease (CHD)?

choices.text: Smoking can cause sudden death from CHD.
Filters in cigarettes are protective against the development of CHD.
Risk of developing CHD 10-20 years after the cessation of smoking is equal in smokers and non smokers.
Degree of risk of developing CHD is directly related to the number of cigarettes smoked per day.

questions.solution:
Filters are probably not protective against the development of coronary heart disease in smokers.

Smoking is a modifiable risk factor for coronary heart disease (CHD). The degree of risk is directly related to the number of cigarettes smoked per day. Several mechanisms have been suggested for this:

  • Carbon monoxide induced atherogenesis
  • Nicotine stimulation of adrenergic drive
  • Lipid metabolism with fall in levels of HDL

Cigarettes also increase the risk of sudden death in patients with CHD who are below 50 years of age. The risk of death from CHD decreases with the cessation of smoking. The risk declines quite substantially within one year of stopping smoking and more gradually thereafter until, after 10- 20 years, it is the same as that of non-smokers.

Risk factors for coronary heart disease are:

  • Modifiable:
    • Cigarette smoking
    • High blood pressure
    • Elevated serum cholesterol
    • Diabetes
    • Obesity
    • Sedentary habits
    • Stress
  • Non-modifiable:
    • Age
    • Sex
    • Family history
    • Genetic factors
    • Personality

questions.text: A chronic smoker was found to have a deranged lipid profile during his annual health checkup. Which of the following variables tested is most directly associated with the risk of developing coronary heart disease?
questions.solution:
The plasma LDL level is most directly associated with the risk of developing coronary heart disease (CHD).

HDL is protective against the development of CHD. Its levels should ideally be more than 40 mg/dl.

Recent evidence shows that levels of Apolipoprotein-A-1 and Apolipoprotein-B are better predictors of CHD than HDL or LDL.

VLDL is more strongly associated with the risk of developing peripheral vascular disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old diabetic male is concerned about his risk of developing coronary heart disease. What cholesterol/HDL ratio would you aim to achieve in this patient?
questions.solution: A cholesterol/HDL ratio <3.5 is recommended for the prevention of coronary heart disease (CHD).

questions.text: While conducting a screening camp for coronary heart disease, you encounter the following people. Who among them is at the highest risk for developing this disease?

choices.text: A person who is competitive and ambitious
A person who is calm and relaxed
A person who tends to suppress their emotions
An introverted person with negative affectivity

questions.solution:
A person who is competitive and ambitious is said to have a type A personality. Such people are more prone to develop coronary heart disease (CHD). Personality type is a non-modifiable risk factor for CHD.

Risk factors for coronary heart disease are:

  • Modifiable:
    • Cigarette smoking
    • High blood pressure
    • Elevated serum cholesterol
    • Diabetes
    • Obesity
    • Sedentary habits
    • Stress
  • Non-modifiable:
    • Age
    • Sex
    • Family history
    • Genetic factors
    • Personality 

Option B: A calm and relaxed person is said to have a type B personality.

Option C: A person who tends to suppress their emotions, especially negative emotions, is said to have a type C personality.

Option D: A person with negative affectivity and social inhibition is said to have a type D personality.

questions.text: A 45-year-old obese woman enquires about ways she can reduce her risk of coronary artery disease. Which of the following dietary modifications would you suggest?

choices.text: Reduction of salt intake to less than 10g per day
Consumption of saturated fats limited to less than 10% of the total energy intake
Reduction of total fat intake to less than 5% of total energy intake
Dietary cholesterol increased to above 100 mg/1000 kcal energy intake

questions.solution:
Limiting the consumption of saturated fats to less than 10% of total energy intake is recommended for the prevention of coronary artery disease.

The WHO'S Expert Committee suggested certain dietary modifications for the prevention of coronary artery disease. These include:

  • Reduction of the total fat intake to 20–30% of total energy intake
  • Consumption of saturated fats must be limited to less than 10% of total energy intake
  • A reduction of dietary cholesterol to below 100mg per 1000 kcal per day
  • Increase in the complex carbohydrate consumption (i.e vegetables, fruits, whole grains and legumes)
  • Avoidance of alcohol consumption and reduction of salt intake to 5g daily or less

questions.text: A 50-year-old man, under treatment for hypertension for the past two months, is found to have a blood pressure of 144/96 mmHg. How will you grade it according to the European society of cardiology guidelines-2018?
questions.solution:
According to the European society of cardiology guidelines-2018, a patient having a systolic BP≥140 and a diastolic BP≥90 mmHg is classified as having grade 1 hypertension.

questions.text: A doctor records the BP of a patient as 142/90mmHg. One hour later, another doctor records the BP of the same patient as 160/98 mmHg. Both the readings are measured with the same apparatus under the same emotional and physical state of the patient. What type of error is seen here?
questions.solution:
Such errors can arise due to differences in hearing acuity and interpretation of Korotkoff sounds.

The types of errors that can occur during the measurement of blood pressure include:

  • Observer errors - due to difference in hearing acuity and interpretation of Korotkoff sounds
  • Instrumental errors - due to a leaking valve or cuffs that do not encircle the arm completely
  • Subject errors - due to anxiety, fear, etc. of the patient

questions.text: What does number 2 in the given diagram related to hypertension denote?

choices.text: Diagnosed hypertensive subjects not on treatment

questions.solution:
The above diagram depicts the "rule of halves", which shows the distribution of hypertension in the community. The number 2 in this diagram denotes normotensive subjects.

The rule of halves is a way of depicting the iceberg phenomenon seen in hypertension. It depicts that only about half of the hypertensive subjects in the general population of most developed countries are aware of the condition and only half of those aware are being treated and only half of those being treated are considered to be adequately treated. 

The circles marked by numbers in the given diagram correspond to the following parts of the population:

  1. Whole community
  2. Normotensive subjects
  3. Hypertensive subjects
  4. Undiagnosed hypertension
  5. Diagnosed hypertension
  6. Diagnosed but untreated
  7. Diagnosed and treated
  8. Inadequately treated
  9. Adequately treated

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding tracking of blood pressure?

choices.text: BP increases with age in all individuals
BP falls steadily in the elderly
Hypertensive children become hypotensive as they grow
BP of hypotensive children tends to remain low in adult life

questions.solution:
If the blood pressure of individuals is followed up over years from early childhood to adult life, low blood pressures tend to remain low and high blood pressures become higher as the individuals grow older. This phenomenon of persistence of the rank order of blood pressure is described as tracking.

This is helpful in identifying children and adolescents who are at risk of developing hypertension in the future.

Although blood pressure is known to increase with age in both sexes, some communities have been identified whose mean blood pressure does not rise with age. This is because their salt intake and calorie consumption are at a subsistence level.

questions.text: Which of the following is a minor criterion for the diagnosis of rheumatic fever in a low risk population?
questions.solution:
Polyarthralgia is a minor criterion for the diagnosis of rheumatic fever in a low risk population.

questions.text: A child having strep throat is being prescribed benzathine penicillin G. Which level of prevention of rheumatic fever does this intervention fall under?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is an example of primary mode of prevention of rheumatic fever. This is because the patient only has strep throat and rheumatic fever has not developed yet.

In case benzathine penicillin G is given to a patient with rheumatic fever to prevent further complications, then it becomes secondary level of prevention.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy with rheumatic fever developed carditis which subsequently healed in a couple of weeks. How long will you administer benzathine penicillin G for secondary prophylaxis to him?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, benzathine penicillin G for secondary prophylaxis should be given for 10 years from the last attack i.e, till 26 years of age. The given case is of rheumatic fever with carditis but with no residual valvular disease, for which secondary prophylaxis is given for 10 years from the last attack or till 21 years of age, whichever is longer. 

Recommendations for the duration of secondary prophylaxis with penicillin:

Category of the patient

Duration of prophylaxis

Rheumatic fever without carditis

For 5 years after the last attack or until 21 years of age ( whichever is longer)

Rheumatic fever with carditis but with no residual valvular disease

For 10 years after the last attack or until 21 yrs of age (whichever is longer)

Rheumatic fever with persistent valvular disease evident clinically or on echo

For 10 years after the last attack or until 40 years of age, or sometimes lifelong prophylaxis

questions.text: Which of the following is not a protective factor for diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
A higher intake of saturated fats is associated with an increased risk of diabetes mellitus.

Dietary factors that are protective for diabetes mellitus are:

  • Higher intake of unsaturated fatty acids
  • A minimum daily intake of 20g of dietary fibre
  • Exclusive breastfeeding

questions.text: A patient's fasting plasma glucose is 122 mg/dl and postprandial plasma glucose is 138 mg/dl. According to the WHO diagnostic criteria for diabetes, which category does this patient fall under?
questions.solution:
Fasting blood glucose of 122 mg/dl with a postprandial value of 138 mg/dl indicates the patient falls under the criteria for impaired fasting glucose.

The WHO diagnostic criteria for diabetes and intermediate hyperglycemia is as follows:

Fasting plasma glucose Post prandial plasma glucose Diagnosis
≥ 126 mg/dl > 200 mg/dl Diabetes
< 126 mg/dl 140-200 mg/dl Impaired glucose tolerance
110-125 mg/dl < 140 mg/dl Impaired fasting glucose

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are incorrect regarding the benefits of various interventions in diabetes?
  1. Lifestyle interventions can reduce the incidence of diabetes by 50%
  2. Risk of microvascular disease reduces by 30% per 1% drop in HbA1c 
  3. Use of ACE inhibitors reduces the risk of nephropathy by 10%
  4. Risk of macrovascular disease reduces by 35% per 10 mmHg drop in blood pressure
  5. Annual eye examination reduces the incidence of serious visual loss by 40%
questions.solution:
The use of ACE inhibitors in diabetics reduces the risk of nephropathy by 42% and cardiovascular risk by 22%. Annual eye examination in diabetics reduces the incidence of serious visual loss by 60-70%.

Interventions in diabetes:

  • Glycaemic control in diabetics with HbA1C > 9% reduces microvascular disease risk by 30% per 1% drop in HbA1c.
  • Blood pressure control in patients with BP > 130/80 mmHg reduces microvascular and macrovascular disease risk by 35% per 10 mmHg drop in blood pressure.
  • Lifestyle modification reduces the incidence of diabetes by 35-58%.
  • Metformin administered as a preventive therapy reduces the incidence of diabetes by 25-31%.
  • Proper foot care reduces the risk of serious foot disease by 50-60%.

questions.text: The community health officer of an area is instructed to assess the population for the risk factors of Non-alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease under NP-NCD. Which of the following will not be a risk factor?
questions.solution:
Low blood pressure is not a risk factor for NAFLD according to the NP-NCD.

The National Programme for Prevention & Control of Non-Communicable Diseases (NP-NCD), which was earlier NPCDCS, has integrated guidelines for the management of Non-alcoholic Fatty Liver disease (NAFLD) into its framework. Through a community-based assessment checklist, the community health officer along with ASHA workers will assess for the presence of the following risk factors:

  1. Abdominal obesity (waist circumference of >90cm in men and >80cm in women)
  2. Personal or family history of diabetes, hypertension, cancers, heart diseases, liver diseases or gallstones
  3. Obesity (BMI >23 kg/m2)
  4. Presence of pedal edema
Level of healthcare Provisions
Community level
  • ASHA workers assess for abdominal obesity, relevant personal or family history.
  • Refer to the sub-health centre.
Sub-Health Centre
  • Validate ASHA workers’ referrals.
  • Further assess for pedal edema, BMI, and screen for other NCDs.
Primary Health Centre
  • Assessment of SHC referrals for signs of chronic liver disease.
  • Basic treatment for DM/HTN.
Community Health Centre
  • Rule out other causes of liver disease, and perform CBC and LFT. Calculate FIB4 or NFS score. 
  • If low risk of fibrosis - Refer back to the PHC for conservative management, weight reduction etc. Reassess in 3 years.
  • If indeterminate, or high risk of fibrosis - Refer to a higher centre.
District level
  • Perform Fibroscan for indeterminate risk of fibrosis.
  • In case of low risk of fibrosis - Refer back to the PHC for conservative management, weight reduction, etc. Reassess in 3 years.
  • In case of high risk of fibrosis - Management of fibrosis, screening for HCC and portal hypertension.
  • Refer complicated cases to tertiary level.
Tertiary level
  • Management of complicated cases.
